p:
Forests cover around one-third of the global land surface, store about half of the terrestrial carbon
15 and are the dominating contributors of terrestrial net primary production
16 . Forests not only provide ecological, economic, and esthetic services to humankind
17 but also mitigate climate warming though evaporative cooling
18 and carbon sequestration
15 . Nonetheless, the fate of forests under climate change with increasing extremes remains uncertain
14 . Anderregg et al.
12 analyzed the legacy effects of extreme droughts on tree radial growth using tree-ring records and models and inferred that carbon storage could decrease as a result of extreme droughts in semi-arid forests. The counterpart of extreme drought is extreme wetness, but how forests respond to the latter
1, 7, 8 has been less studied.
